docs.snippet: Eustace Tilley Makes a Return      Although no substantiation is offered for HENDRIK HERTZBERG'S claim on The New Yorker's new Web site that EUSTACE TILLEY, the persnickety snob created by REA IRVIN, is ''one of the most successful and recognizabl...
docs.lead_paragraph: Eustace Tilley Makes a Return Although no substantiation is offered for HENDRIK HERTZBERG'S claim on The New Yorker's new Web site that EUSTACE TILLEY, the persnickety snob created by REA IRVIN, is ''one of the most successful and recognizable corporate trademarks in the history of hype,'' Mr. Tilley does have a lengthy curriculum vitae. He appeared on The New Yorker's first cover on Feb. 21, 1925, and each February thereafter until 1994. Then, the satire was itself deemed ripe for satire, by TINA BROWN, the editor at the time. A skinny Times Square loiterer with a certain resemblance to Eustace appeared on the anniversary cover, drawn by R. CRUMB. Mr. Tilley was subsequently sent up by the likes of ART SPIEGELMAN and WILLIAM WEGMAN.
docs.abstract: Public Lives column; Eustace Tilley, character created by Rea Irvin, returns to New Yorker magazine cover for first time sinceFebruary 1994; scene at World of Barbie showroom at FAO Schwarz described; actor Jeremy Irons discusses his participating in BT Global Challenge around the world yact race (M)

byline.original: By SHAILA K. DEWAN, with Linda Lee and Glenn Collins

docs.snippet: Juan Tovar Santos, an assembly-line worker in this border city, will not forget the time he traveled to Alcoa's annual shareholders meeting in Pittsburgh and confronted the chief executive about working conditions in Alcoa factories here.    After...
docs.lead_paragraph: Juan Tovar Santos, an assembly-line worker in this border city, will not forget the time he traveled to Alcoa's annual shareholders meeting in Pittsburgh and confronted the chief executive about working conditions in Alcoa factories here. After Paul H. O'Neill, the Alcoa chief executive who became President Bush's treasury secretary last month, trumpeted the company's growing profits, Mr. Tovar stepped to a microphone. At the time Mr. Tovar, who was earning about $6 a day, described Alcoa managers so stingy that they stationed a janitor at bathroom doors to limit workers to just three pieces of toilet paper. He also recounted an incident in which more than 100 workers had been overcome by fumes from a gas leak and taken to hospitals.
docs.abstract: Latest article in Dividing Line series on life along Mexican side of border, on rules, written and unwritten, under which mostly American corporations operate on border; there is rising concern that as factories spread through developing world, labor rights and environmental standards are being overlooked; Mexico's government began offering tax-exempt status to border assembly plants in late 1960's, and over years Mexico and its people came to accept poor working conditions and low pay in return for steady jobs; in Acuna, tensions have flared with Alcoa, which has eight plants there; despite Alcoa's wage increases and improvements in factory conditions, Acuna workers still live in squalid grid of dirt streets, rotting garbage and swamps of open sewage; some officials are beginning to question whether Mexico benefits from tax breaks given to foreign companies; photos; map (L)

headline.main: Profits Raise Pressures On U.S.-Owned Factories In Mexican Border Zone

docs.snippet: He may laugh. He may let you tickle him. But yesterday it became clear that not even something as cute as Elmo is safe from economic change. Employees had a hard time not making Oscar the Grouch jokes yesterday, as the Sesame Workshop, the nonprof...
docs.lead_paragraph: He may laugh. He may let you tickle him. But yesterday it became clear that not even something as cute as Elmo is safe from economic change. Employees had a hard time not making Oscar the Grouch jokes yesterday, as the Sesame Workshop, the nonprofit education organization that created the ''Sesame Street'' television show, laid off 60 workers and said it would turn over the production and marketing of its Sesame Street Magazine, which is geared to children, to Time Inc., and close its other magazine, Sesame Street Parents. The financial details of the 10-year agreement were not disclosed yesterday. Sesame Workshop changed its name from the Children's Television Workshop last year. The magazines are bundled together and have an estimated 1.1 million readers. Beginning in October, Sesame Street Magazine will be packaged with Parenting, which is published by the Parenting Group, a division of Time Inc. Sesame Workshop will continue to provide the editorial content for Sesame Street Magazine. Jayson Blair
docs.abstract: Sesame Workshop, nonprofit education organization that created Sesame Street television show, lays off 60 workers; says it will turn over production of marketing of its Sesame Street Magazine to Time Inc; photo (S)

headline.main: Metro Business Briefing; SESAME STREET-TIME INC. DEAL

docs.snippet: Ang Lee, the director of ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,'' was at the front desk of his New York hotel, checking in after a long night of shooting in New Jersey, when his publicist reached him with the news. Joan Allen, star of ''The Contender,'...
docs.lead_paragraph: Ang Lee, the director of ''Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon,'' was at the front desk of his New York hotel, checking in after a long night of shooting in New Jersey, when his publicist reached him with the news. Joan Allen, star of ''The Contender,'' had just taken a shower with her pet parrot and was watching the Oscar nominations in her Upper West Side apartment while blow-drying the bird. (''You're not supposed to let them get a chill.'') Javier Bardem, a star of ''Before Night Falls,'' was alone at home in Madrid, having a beer, when the news came across Spanish television. And Jeff Bridges, best supporting actor nominee for ''The Contender,'' was being worked on by the makeup artist Edouard Henriques, nominated for ''The Cell,'' while nearby the cinematographer John Mathieson, nominated for ''Gladiator,'' was preparing for a shot. ''We're pretty happy around here,'' Mr. Bridges said.
docs.abstract: Nominations for 73rd annual Academy Awards are announced, and film with most nominations is Gladiator (12), closely followed by Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (10); two Steven Soderbergh films, Erin Brockovich and Traffic, get five nominations each; nominees tell what they were doing when they got the news; photos (M)

headline.main: 'Gladiator,' 'Crouching Tiger' and Soderbergh Are Oscar Nominees

docs.snippet: Sometimes a fashion show provides such an exquisite keyhole into a certain kind of life -- specifically, the status life of New York -- that automatically your mind starts reeling off all these little scenes, very Upper East Side, very Mario Buatt...
docs.lead_paragraph: Sometimes a fashion show provides such an exquisite keyhole into a certain kind of life -- specifically, the status life of New York -- that automatically your mind starts reeling off all these little scenes, very Upper East Side, very Mario Buatta, with the pillows creased just so and all these blond divorcées ready to carve each other up while they slowly pick their way through their rare hamburgers at Swifty's and wonder what became of Mr. Right in St. Bart's. Such were the little scenes conjured by Oscar de la Renta's collection yesterday. The show was so dead-on in the way it covered all those significant lifestyle bases -- from the classy tweed skirt and sweater that Carmen Kass wore out at the beginning to the let-them-eat-cake ball gowns at the end -- that one could see the places these clothes would go. And the things that would happen in them -- well, that is the giddy part about fashion.
docs.abstract: Cathy Horyn reviews fashions at Oscar de la Renta's show at New York Fall 2001 in New York City; photo (M)

headline.main: Review/Fashion; Creating a Fantasy Life Beyond the Seams

docs.snippet: For months now, Aleksei Uchitel, 49, a Russian movie director, has been taking his latest film, ''His Wife's Diary,'' around two continents, from an assortment of festivals in Moscow, New York, Milan and the Czech Republic to a private screening l...
docs.lead_paragraph: For months now, Aleksei Uchitel, 49, a Russian movie director, has been taking his latest film, ''His Wife's Diary,'' around two continents, from an assortment of festivals in Moscow, New York, Milan and the Czech Republic to a private screening last week at the Library of Congress in Washington. But for Mr. Uchitel the only prize that really counts will be announced in Los Angeles tomorrow, when the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences presents its Oscar nominees, including the five finalists for best foreign-language film.
docs.abstract: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences is set to announce five finalists for best foreign-language film; this year record 46 countries have entered films in foreign-language category; tortuous process of getting nominated described; photos (M)

headline.main: The Long, Felliniesque Road to Hollywood; For Foreign-Language Films in Search of an Oscar, Obstacles at Every Turn

docs.snippet: ''Hannibal,'' Ridley Scott's Grand Guignol feast of blood lust, ravenous boars and sautéed brains, has earned an estimated $58 million in its first weekend, the third-biggest three-day film opening ever.     Hollywood was expecting a huge opening...
docs.lead_paragraph: ''Hannibal,'' Ridley Scott's Grand Guignol feast of blood lust, ravenous boars and sautéed brains, has earned an estimated $58 million in its first weekend, the third-biggest three-day film opening ever. Hollywood was expecting a huge opening for ''Hannibal,'' the sequel to the 1991 Oscar-winning ''Silence of the Lambs,'' but this was well beyond even the most optimistic projections. This total would have been impressive for a summer holiday weekend. But for February, it was astonishing.
docs.abstract: Ridley Scott's movie, Hannibal, earns estimated $58 million in its first weekend, third-biggest three-day film opening ever; No. 2 movie of weekend is The Wedding Planner, earning $7.8 million; Saving Silverman, new comedy, earns $7.4 million in opening weekend; fourth-place film, Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon, earns $5.1 million (M)

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-15    Fuel-Short Region in Russia Is Now Freezing in the Dark  One of the most mismanaged and corrupt of Russia's 89 regions is suffering a devastating fuel shortage for the fourth winter in a row, in a nation that boasts the la...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Fuel-Short Region in Russia Is Now Freezing in the Dark One of the most mismanaged and corrupt of Russia's 89 regions is suffering a devastating fuel shortage for the fourth winter in a row, in a nation that boasts the largest coal reserve on earth. President Vladimir V. Putin has pledged to bring such wayward regions back under central control. The Primorsky Region may be his first major test. A1 Protest Against Ukraine Leader Thousands of demonstrators marched through Kiev, the second such outpouring in a week, demanding the resignation of President Leonid D. Kuchma and calling for new presidential elections. Political parties have united in opposition over allegations of scandal. A8

docs.snippet: TWO days until the Academy Award nominations are announced, and already Steven Soderbergh's ERIN BROCKOVICH (2000), a film generating serious Oscar talk for its star, Julia Roberts, is on premium cable. Ms. Roberts plays the title character, a fin...
docs.lead_paragraph: TWO days until the Academy Award nominations are announced, and already Steven Soderbergh's ERIN BROCKOVICH (2000), a film generating serious Oscar talk for its star, Julia Roberts, is on premium cable. Ms. Roberts plays the title character, a financially desperate single mother who wangles a job as a legal assistant for an ambulance chaser in a cheap toupee (Albert Finney) and finds herself saving the world. Well, at least one town, where toxic chemicals are in the water supply. The film, based on the life of a real person (who has been turning up on talk and awards shows herself), deteriorates into a do-gooder soap opera, but Ms. Roberts, memorable in micro-mini hemlines, deep cleavage and cheap jewelry, keeps things lively -- Saturday at 8 p.m. and Saturday/Early Sunday at 3:20 a.m. on Starz.
